Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mechanisms of Phytoplankton Community Re-organization Under Global Change
Award.AbstractNarration: Fresh water is becoming a major limiting resource worldwide. Global environmental change is exacerbating freshwater limitation by negatively affecting not only water quantity but quality as well, through stimulating harmful algal blooms (HABs) in waterbodies across the globe. This project aims to understand and predict how and when communities of microscopic algae in lakes shift towards dominance by the toxic algae (cyanobacteria in particular) responsible for most HABs in freshwaters. Using lake sampling in Michigan and mathematical models, Litchman will explore how global warming alters lake water movement and thus conditions such as light and temperature that affect algae growth, including toxic cyanobacteria. Because many HABs can increase the availability of nitrogen in the water, the project will also investigate how changing nutrient availability affects interactions among algal groups. Finally, Litchman will explore how rapid evolutionary response of harmful cyanobacteria to changing climate shapes community composition of microscopic algae and impacts water quality. During this award, Litchman will teach a new course on Field Aquatic Ecology at Michigan State University for advanced undergraduate and graduate students focusing on the effects of global environmental change on aquatic ecosystems. Teachers from local rural schools will work with the PI to develop age-appropriate learning activities on aquatic ecology, water quality issues and global change. Undergraduate and graduate students will participate in the project as will local lake residents and lake associations who will aid in sampling efforts to detect HAB-forming species. Litchman will collaborate with European colleagues on adapting lake physics models to predict HAB occurrences in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: The main goal of this project was to investigate how anthropogenic changes, including climate change and increased nutrient inputs affect communities of phytoplankton, the microscopic algae in lakes, and what conditions lead to an increase in the occurrence and persistence of Harmful Algal Blooms (HABs). Understanding the mechanisms linking climate, nutrient inputs and phytoplankton community composition is crucial for our ability to predict what will happen to freshwater aquatic ecosystems and water quality in the future.

We found that temperature, especially the nighttime temperature, strongly affects the degree of physical mixing in lakes, which in turn greatly affects the growth of the dominant harmful cyanobacterium Microcystis. Higher temperatures decrease mixing, which stimulates Microcystis growth. Interestingly, most other, nonharmful algae were not as strongly affected by lake mixing. Temperature was also a strong driver of bacterial communities in the lakes we sampled, suggesting that future temperature changes will lead to changes in bacterial community structure and function.

We also found that nutrient concentrations and ratios of nitrogen to phosphorus control the composition of phytoplankton communities and that harmful cyanobacteria capable of fixing nitrogen from the atmosphere are stimulated by low N:P ratios, but only under high light. We also found that the predictability of phytoplankton communities depends on the the degree of taxonomic resolution and that at coarser taxonomic levels, e.g., cyanobacteria vs. green algae, the predictability is better. At the level of species, the predictability declines.

Within this project we also developed novel approaches of characterizing phytoplankton communities based on important traits of the constituent species such as their growth rates, abilities to compete for resources and resist grazers. We found that major taxonomic groups of phytoplankton differ significantly in many of their eco-physiological traits and these differences may explain how different environmental conditions select for certain groups, including harmful cyanobacteria.

In summary, the project revealed mechanistic links between climate, nutrient levels and algal composition and increased our knowledge of ecology of different phytoplankton species, including harmful algae. Its results should be useful for aquatic ecologists, environmental scientists and water quality managers. The project increased our understanding understanding of how phytoplankton communities are organized and may reorganize in the future.

Broader Impacts: The results of the project were disseminated widely through publications, presentations to scientific and non-scientific audiences, including high school students and residents in rural Michigan. Three graduate students, one international visiting student, numerous undergraduate students and two technical assistants were trained on this project. The results of the project were also incorporated into two courses the PI teaches and high school hands on educational exercises on global change, aquatic ecology, harmful algal blooms and water quality.
